Select.pm

00001 
00002 #Construct for selection list.
00003 #Inherits from ChoiceList.pm
00004 #VS 6/16/2000
00005 
00006 =head1 NAME
00007 
00008     Select.pm -- sub-class of ChoiceList that implements a select list.
00009 
00010     All items accessed by $out = $sl -> item( $in );
00011 
00012 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00013 
00014 Select.pm is intended to be used to create standard true/false questions
00015 or questions where all the questions have the same set of short one to
00016 two word answers as possible answers. Unlike a matching list, where
00017 answers are indicated by typing in the corresponding letter, in a select
00018 list the actual answer is typed in.  A select list also has the option
00019 of having a pop-up list of the answers so that the correct answer
00020 can just be selected instead of typed. But like match lists, students
00021 can be given different sets of questions (to avoid students sharing
00022 answers) by entering many questions and then having each student only
00023 receive a sub-set of those questions by using choose.
00024 
00025 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00026 
00027 =head2 Variables and methods available to Select
00028 
00029 =head3 Variables
00030 
00031     questions           # array of questions as entered using qa()
00032     answers             # array of answers as entered using qa()
00033 
00034     selected_q          # randomly selected subset of "questions"
00035     selected_a          # the answers for the selected questions
00036 
00037     ans_rule_len        # determines the length of the answer blanks
00038                         # default is 4
00039 
00040     slice               # index used to select specific questions
00041     shuffle             # permutation array which can be applied to slice
00042                         # to shuffle the answers
00043 
00044     inverted_shuffle    # the inverse permutation array
00045 
00046     rf_print_q          # reference to any subroutine which should
00047                         # take ($self, @questions) as parameters and
00048                         # output the questions in a formatted string.
00049                         # If you want to change the way questions are
00050                         # printed, write your own print method and set
00051                         # this equal to a reference to to that method
00052                         # (i.e. $sl->rf_print_q = ~~&printing_routine_q)
00053 
00054     rf_print_a          # reference to any subroutine which should
00055                         # take ($self, @answers) as parameters and
00056                         # output the answers in a formatted string.
00057                         # If you want to change the way answers are
00058                         # printed, write your own print method and set
00059                         # this equal to a reference to to that method
00060                         # (i.e. $sl->rf_print_a = ~~&printing_routine_a)
00061 
00062 =head3 Methods
00063 
00064     qa( array )         # accepts an array of strings which can be used
00065                         # for questions and answers
00066 
00067     print_q             # yields a formatted string of question to be
00068                         # matched with answer blanks
00069 
00070     choose([3, 4], 1)   # chooses questions indexed 3 and 4 and one other
00071                         # randomly
00072 
00073     ra_correct_ans      # outputs a reference to the array of correct answers
00074 
00075 =head2 Usage
00076 
00077 
00078 =head3 Regualar Select List
00079 
00080 
00081 Create a select list using the new_select_list call.
00082 
00083 =for html
00084     <PRE>
00085     <I>$sl = new_select_list;</I>
00086     </PRE>
00087 
00088 Use qa() to enter questions and answers in alternating pairs.
00089 
00090 =for html
00091      <PRE>
00092      <I>$sl->qa(
00093         '\( y = x^2 \) is increasing to the right',
00094         'T',
00095         '\( y = x^3 \) is decreasing to the right',
00096         'F',
00097         '\( y = -x^2 + x^3 + 2 \) is decreasing to the right',
00098         'F',
00099         '\( y = -x^2 + x - 15 \) is decreasing to the left',
00100         'F',
00101         '\( y = 2^x \) is decreasing to the left',
00102         'T',
00103     );</I></PRE>
00104 
00105 After calling qa, use choose to select which questions and/or how many each
00106 student sees. A list of numbers in brackets indicates which questions every
00107 student sees (counting starts with 0) and the final number outside of brackets
00108 is how many more questions should be randomly picked for each student.
00109 
00110 =for html
00111     <PRE>
00112     <I>$sl->choose([0], 1);</I></PRE>
00113 
00114 would show the first question and a random question while
00115 
00116 =for html
00117     <PRE>
00118     <I>$sl->choose(3);</I></PRE>
00119 
00120 would show 3 random questions (but never call choose more than once).
00121 
00122 If you want you can change the size of the answer boxes at any time (the default is 4).
00123 
00124 =for html
00125     <PRE>
00126     <I>$sl->ans_rule_len = 10;</I></PRE>
00127 
00128 Now you would start your problem with a BEGIN_TEXT tag and print the questions
00129 with the print_q() command. Within the BEGIN_TEXT/END_TEXT block, all calls to
00130 objects must be enclosed in \( \).  (The $PAR start a new paragraph by printing
00131 a blank line).
00132 
00133 =for html
00134     <PRE>
00135     <I>BEGIN_TEXT
00136         $PAR
00137         \{ $sl->print_q() \}
00138     END_TEXT</I></PRE>
00139 
00140 Now all that''s left is sending the students answers to the answer evaluator
00141 along with the correct answers so that the students answers can be checked and
00142 a score can be given.  This is done using ANS, an answer evaluator and the
00143 ra_correct_ans variable.
00144 
00145 =for html
00146     <PRE>
00147     <I>ANS(str_cmp($sl->ra_correct_ans));</I></PRE>
00148 
00149 
00150 =head3 Pop-Up Select List
00151 
00152 
00153 A Pop-up select list problem is identical to a regular select list problem with
00154 only a few exceptions.
00155 
00156 First, you would create a pop-up select list using the new_pop_up_select_list call.
00157 
00158 =for html
00159     <PRE>
00160     <I>$sl = new_pop_up_select_list;</I>
00161     </PRE>
00162 
00163 Then you would use qa() and choose() (and optionally ans_rule_len) as normal but
00164 before writing the actual problem within the BEGIN_TEXT/END_TEXT headers, you could
00165 optionally specify value=>label pairs for the pop-up list where you first specify
00166 the value of an answer to one of your questions and you link it to a label (using =>)
00167 that will be shown to the students.  For example,
00168 
00169 =for html
00170     <PRE>
00171     <I>$sl->ra_pop_up_list([no_answer => '  ?', T => 'True', F => 'False']);</I></PRE>
00172 
00173 indicates that instead of seeing the letter T (which was used as the actual
00174 answer), the student will see the word 'True'.  Also, before they choose
00175 their answer the student will first see a question mark in each pop-up list
00176 indicating that they have not yet selected an answer there because the special
00177 variable no_answer has been selected.  This is optional, however, because if no
00178 $sl->ra_pop_up_list is specified, it will default to the one shown above.  So if
00179 this is want you want, you don't need to do any of this, but if you use ra_pop_up_list
00180 at all, these defaults will be lost and 'T' will just be 'T'.  Also, if you don't
00181 specify a label for a particular answer, the label for that answer will be the
00182 answer (like I just said, 'T' will be 'T').
00183 
00184 Other than those two differences, a pop-up select list problem is exactly the same
00185 as a regular select list problem as described above.
00186 
00187 =cut
00188 
00189 BEGIN {
00190     be_strict();
00191 }
00192 #'
00193 package Select;
00194 
00195 
00196 @Select::ISA = qw( Exporter ChoiceList );
00197 
00198 # *** Subroutines which overload ChoiceList.pm ***
00199 
00200 #these
00201 sub extra { warn "Select lists do not use extra answers.\n(You can't use \$sl->extra().)" }
00202 sub choose_extra { warn "Select lists do not use extra answers.\n(You can't use \$sl->choose_extra().)" }
00203 sub makeLast { warn "Select lists do not use extra answers.\n(You can't use \$sl->makeLast().)" }
00204 
00205 #overload choose so that the answers don't get randomized
00206 sub choose {
00207     my $self = shift;
00208     my @input = @_;
00209 
00210 
00211     $self->getRandoms(scalar(@{ $self->{questions} }), @input);
00212     $self->selectQA();
00213     $self->dumpExtra();
00214 }
00215 
00216 sub selectQA {
00217     my $self = shift;
00218 
00219     $self->{selected_q} = [ @{ $self->{questions} }[ @{ $self->{slice} } ] ];
00220     $self->{selected_a} = [ @{ $self->{answers} }[@{ $self->{slice} } ] ];
00221     $self->{inverted_shuffle} = [ &ChoiceList::invert(@{ $self->{shuffle} }) ];
00222 }
